elements.content: We report the synthesis, structure, and magnetism of two coordination polymers with a designed network topology. These isostructural materials are hydrothermally crystallized having a composition of M(en)(ox) (en = ethylenediamine, ox = oxalate, M = Co(II) 1 and Ni(II) 2). The structures show a rare bridging mode of ethylenediamine which links linear [M(ox)]∞ chains into an oblique two-dimensional network. Both compounds show antiferromagnetic interactions behaving as one-dimensional magnets. The magnetism of 1 is consistent with an S = 3/2 chain affected by spin−orbit coupling (g = 2.814(2), J/k B = −16.03(3) K, D/k B = 86.2(4) K), while 2 is a candidate Haldane antiferromagnet (g = 2.194(2), J/k B = −39.3(1), E g/k B = 16.5 K). We discuss the use of models for S = 3/2 antiferromagnetic chains and present our own polynomial for Heisenberg S = 3/2 antiferromagnetic chains.

elements.content: We present two 2-D network compounds built from [M(II)(oxalate)]∞ chains (M = Co, 1; Ni, 2) bridged into 2-D networks by ethylenediamine. Both show antiferromagnetic interactions (1: J/k B = −16.03(3) K; 2: J/k B = −39.3(1) K), and 2 is a candidate Haldane antiferromagnet.

elements.content: The combination of a metal ion and the oxalate dianion provides a rich variety of extended coordination networks. The structural chemistry of oxalate is well described, with the chelating and bridging coordination modes offering a degree of local structural predictability. This makes metal oxalates useful systems in the design and synthesis of inorganic coordination polymers in one, two, and three dimensions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The combination of a metal ion and the oxalate dianion provides a rich variety of extended coordination networks. The structural chemistry of oxalate is well described, with the chelating and bridging coordination modes offering a degree of local structural predictability. This makes metal oxalates useful systems in the design and synthesis of inorganic coordination polymers in one, two, and three dimensions.

elements.content: Magnetically, oxalate is well-known to mediate strong superexchange couplings between paramagnetic metal centers. The strength of the magnetic interaction is very dependent on the coordination geometry of the bridging oxalate and on the coordination sphere of the paramagnetic ions. In rare cases, this exchange interaction can be very small, but typically the values are large. For example, Cu(ox)·xH2O has a coupling interaction; |J|/k B = 298 K. In homometallic compounds, this interaction is antiferromagnetic, but by careful combination of metal ions (e.g., CrIII and NiII), ferromagnetic interactions can also be engineered if the magnetic orbitals of the metals are strictly orthogonal.
elements.clean_text: Magnetically, oxalate is well-known to mediate strong superexchange couplings between paramagnetic metal centers. The strength of the magnetic interaction is very dependent on the coordination geometry of the bridging oxalate and on the coordination sphere of the paramagnetic ions. In rare cases, this exchange interaction can be very small, but typically the values are large. For example, Cu(ox)⋅xH2O has a coupling interaction; |J|/k B = 298 K. In homometallic compounds, this interaction is antiferromagnetic, but by careful combination of metal ions (e.g., CrIII and NiII), ferromagnetic interactions can also be engineered if the magnetic orbitals of the metals are strictly orthogonal.

elements.content: We have been investigating the design and synthesis of various metal oxalate frameworks, and a growing part of this work has been the use of amines to direct structure. We have previously reported Ni(ox)(pip) [ox = oxalate, pip = piperazine] in which the semirigid diamine links chains of [Ni(ox)]∞ into a two-dimensional (2-D) grid. Because of the relative metal−metal separations, through the Ni-ox-Ni and Ni-pip-Ni pathways, and the efficiency of the oxalate and the piperazine to mediate magnetic exchange interactions, this compound behaves as a one-dimensional (1-D) magnet. While there are many examples of [M(ox)]∞ chain compounds, the way in which these chains pack is usually governed by van der Waals or weak hydrogen bonding interactions. Consequently, it is difficult to predict or control the magnetic interchain interactions. On the basis of the structure of Ni(ox)(pip) and the related structures of Ni(ox)(4,4′-bipy), we set out to see whether other diamines could be used to direct the same type of 2-D grid structure, in which a 1-D [M(ox)]∞ chain could be held in a rigid framework. This would be the first step to control the magnetic behavior in such systems.

elements.content: We chose ethylenediamine (en) as our structure directing amine. This conformationally flexible ligand with a well-known and dominant capacity for chelation seems an unlikely bridge, and a strange choice of amine. However, since the flexibility of the ligand increases the likelihood that other structures could be formed, success in forming the 2-D structure would allow us to comment on the robustness and stability of the 2-D net. Such a synthesis clearly requires control of the stoichiometry of the components, in order to control the nature of the solution species while these two competing ligands are interacting with the metal ions. It is also important to control the overall concentration and avoid the immediate precipitation of an amorphous solid. Given the highly insoluble nature of the products, crystallization under hydrothermal conditions seems a logical synthetic starting point.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

Infrared spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer between 4000 and 400 cm-1 in a KBr matrix. UV/vis/NIR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 19 spectrophotometer in diffuse reflectance mode with the samples embedded in a BaSO4 matrix. C, H, and N elemental analysis was performed by Medac Ltd. (Surrey, UK).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray data were collected with Mo Kα radiation (0.71073 Å) on an Enraf Nonius KappaCCD area detector as ϕ and ω scans to fill the Ewald sphere. Data collection and cell refinement were managed by DENZO, an empirical absorption correction was applied using SORTAV, structure solution was obtained by direct methods (SIR92), and full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 (SHELXL97) was performed in the WinGX environment. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized geometries with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.2 × U eq of the parent atom, and then refined in riding mode. Crystallographic data for compounds 1 [Co(C2O4)(C2N2H8)] and 2 [Ni(C2O4)(C2N2H8)] have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publications CCDC 267638 (1) and CCDC 237639 (2). Samples were checked for phase purity by powder X-ray diffraction using a Siemens D5000 diffractometer. Field-cooled magnetization measurements were made between 1.8 and 290 K using a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer in applied fields of 200 G. The powdered samples were embedded in an eicosane matrix to prevent reorientation effects. Diamagnetic corrections were determined from Pascal’s constants.

elements.content: CoSO4·7H2O (281 mg, 1.00 mmol), ethylenediamine (0.2 mL, 3.0 mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (127 mg, 1.00 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) were heated in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr) to 150 °C under autogenious pressure for 72 h. Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a brown microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 38 mg (18%).

Synthesis of Co(en)(ox) (1)

CoSO4⋅7H2O (281 mg, 1.00 mmol), ethylenediamine (0.2 mL, 3.0 mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (127 mg, 1.00 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) were heated in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr) to 150 °C under autogenious pressure for 72 h. Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a brown microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 38 mg (18%).

Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a blue microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 60 mg (27%).

The compound Co(ox)(en) (where ox = oxalate and en = ethylenediamine) (1) crystallizes in the centered monoclinic space group C2/m (No. 12). The asymmetric unit contains only a quarter of the empirical formula. We note that each of the components, the cobalt(II) cation, the oxalate dianion, and the neutral ethylenediamine, all experience a local C 2h symmetry. In the case of the amine this is the maximum possible symmetry of this molecule, while the oxalate anion is reduced from the maximum theoretical symmetry of D 2h . Each Co ion is coordinated by two chelating oxalate ions and by two monodentate ethylenediamine molecules (Figure ). The trans-N2O4 coordination sphere of the Co atom is approximately octahedral with a slight axial elongation in the N−Co−N direction. The Co−O and Co−N bond distances are 2.115(2) and 2.159(9) Å, respectively. The normalized bite angle of the oxalate to the Co atom is 1.27°. The oxalate anions also symmetrically bridge neighboring Co atoms to form planar chains of [Co(ox)]∞ running along the c-axis with a Co···Co separation equal to the c-parameter of 5.494(1) Å. The ethylenediamine molecules adopt the low-energy all-trans configuration. They bridge cobalt(II) ions to form chains running parallel to the a-axis, with a Co···Co separation equal to the a-parameter of 7.648(2) Å. Together the two types of linkage form an electrically neutral two-dimensional oblique network of [Co(ox)(en)]∞ in the ac-plane (Figure ). The sheets of this 2-D metal−organic framework (MOF) stack in a staggered fashion forming a highly symmetric set of N−H···O and C−H···O close contacts between the ethylenediamine and the oxalato components (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The compound Co(ox)(en) (where ox = oxalate and en = ethylenediamine) (1) crystallizes in the centered monoclinic space group C2/m (No. 12). The asymmetric unit contains only a quarter of the empirical formula. We note that each of the components, the cobalt(II) cation, the oxalate dianion, and the neutral ethylenediamine, all experience a local C 2h  symmetry. In the case of the amine this is the maximum possible symmetry of this molecule, while the oxalate anion is reduced from the maximum theoretical symmetry of D 2h . Each Co ion is coordinated by two chelating oxalate ions and by two monodentate ethylenediamine molecules (Figure ). The trans-N2O4 coordination sphere of the Co atom is approximately octahedral with a slight axial elongation in the N-Co-N direction. The Co-O and Co-N bond distances are 2.115(2) and 2.159(9) Å, respectively. The normalized bite angle of the oxalate to the Co atom is 1.27°. The oxalate anions also symmetrically bridge neighboring Co atoms to form planar chains of [Co(ox)]∞ running along the c-axis with a Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation equal to the c-parameter of 5.494(1) Å. The ethylenediamine molecules adopt the low-energy all-trans configuration. They bridge cobalt(II) ions to form chains running parallel to the a-axis, with a Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation equal to the a-parameter of 7.648(2) Å. Together the two types of linkage form an electrically neutral two-dimensional oblique network of [Co(ox)(en)]∞ in the ac-plane (Figure ). The sheets of this 2-D metal-organic framework (MOF) stack in a staggered fashion forming a highly symmetric set of N-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅O close contacts between the ethylenediamine and the oxalato components (Figure ).

elements.content: The compound Ni(ox)(en); 2 (, ) is isostructural to 1. The largest difference in the structures concerns the coordination of the metals. As expected in 2 we see a slightly more compact coordination sphere with Ni−O and Ni−N distances of 2.080(2) and 2.118(2) Å, respectively, and thus decreased M···M separations of 5.397(5) Å across the oxalate and 7.571(5) Å across the ethylenediamine bridge. The normalized bite angle of the oxalate to the Ni atom is 1.30°.

elements.content: The oblique 2-D network structure shown by 1 and 2 has been observed in a number of other transition metal oxalates, where planar [M(ox)]∞ chains linked together by diamine bridges. In particular, we note the similarity to Ni(ox)(pip) (where pip = piperazine) 3, in which a similar high degree of local symmetry is also observed, with the nickel, oxalate, and piperazine all being found on crystallographic inversion centers in the space group P1̅.

In particular, we note the similarity to Ni(ox)(pip) (where pip = piperazine) 3, in which a similar high degree of local symmetry is also observed, with the nickel, oxalate, and piperazine all being found on crystallographic inversion centers in the space group P1̅.

elements.content: This observed bridging coordination mode of ethylenediamine is rare, with conventional chelation dominating the chemistry of this ligand. Known examples of compounds containing bridging ethylenediamine units are mostly dinuclear structures, although a few extended structures (chains, sheets, and 3-D networks) are reported. We note two reports of compounds where metal−ligand chains are bridged by ethylenediamine to form oblique 2-D nets with the same topology as described for 1 (and 2). In fact, there are few instances where both oxalate and ethylenediamine occur together in a coordination compound, with some examples of mononuclear and dinuclear compounds and fewer polynuclear chains. It is clear from known structures that the chelating amine tends to displace the oxalate ion, which is often present as a charge balancing counteranion.

Known examples of compounds containing bridging ethylenediamine units are mostly dinuclear structures, although a few extended structures (chains, sheets, and 3-D networks) are reported. We note two reports of compounds where metal-ligand chains are bridged by ethylenediamine to form oblique 2-D nets with the same topology as described for 1 (and 2). In fact, there are few instances where both oxalate and ethylenediamine occur together in a coordination compound, with some examples of mononuclear and dinuclear compounds and fewer polynuclear chains. It is clear from known structures that the chelating amine tends to displace the oxalate ion, which is often present as a charge balancing counteranion.

elements.content: While these networks have a structurally 2-D character, only the oxalate ligand mediates a significant magnetic superexchange interaction. Thus, it is primarily the [M(ox)]∞ network that determines the magnetic behavior, and it is pertinent to examine other metal oxalate chain structures. Early work has focused on the simple binary metal oxalates, in particular, [M(ox)(H2O)2] (M = Co, Ni) which have the same structure as the mineral Humboldtine. The past decade has seen a large increase in the known [MII(ox)]∞ chain compounds. There are now many examples of linear [Co(ox)]∞ chains, where the metal is octahedrally coordinated and the oxalate anions have a trans-geometry, as well as many zigzag chains, where the octahedral metal is coordinated by the oxalate ions in a cis-geometry. Not surprisingly, there are many similar examples of linear [Ni(ox)]∞ chains, and zigzag [Ni(ox)]∞ chains.

elements.content:
Compound 1 is brown, although the 4T1 g(F) → 4T1 g(P) process occurs at the same energy as it does in the pink hexaaquacobalt(II) species.

The approximately octahedral N2O4 coordination sphere of the Ni(II) ion in 2 causes the 3F term to split, giving rise to a 3A2 g ground state. The electronic spectrum of 2 is consistent with this, and all of the d−d transitions can be assigned. The crystal field splitting parameter, Δoct, is determined as 9700 cm−1, the energy of the higher lying 3P term as 10 330 cm−1 and the percentage covalency, β°, as 34.8%. Comparison with the properties of systems with NiO6 and NiN6 coordination spheres shows that 1 is intermediate between the two, as would be expected (Table ). A forbidden transition to the 1Eg state is present at 14 400 cm−1 and is enhanced by mixing with a nearby 3T1 g(F) state.

The magnetic susceptibility of 1 (Figure ) shows a broad maximum at 18 K with χ max = 37.56 × 10−3 cm3 mol−1 before decreasing. The inverse susceptibility plot shows linear behavior above ∼160 K, and modeling the data with the Curie−Weiss equation gives a Curie constant, C = 3.72(1) cm3 mol−1 K and a Weiss constant, θ = −61.4(9) K. On cooling, the χT(T) plot decreases from a value of 3.07 cm3 mol−1 K at 290 K. From C and χT (290 K), we can obtain g-values of 2.82 and 2.56, respectively. The lower estimate of the g-value from χT (290 K) is due to not having reached the asymptotic limit at this temperature. Our expectation in this system is fairly straightforward. The octahedrally coordinated Co(II) ion has an orbitally degenerate ground state and generally shows a significantly anisotropic spin moment. In particular, the zero-field splitting, D is often comparable in energy to typical superexchange interactions, J. In this case only the oxalate bridges provide a significant exchange interaction, and so we expect the compound to behave as a 1-D chain of interacting spins, as described by the Hamiltonian, eq . H = − J ∑ i S i · S i + 1

The octahedrally coordinated Co(II) ion has an orbitally degenerate ground state and generally shows a significantly anisotropic spin moment. In particular, the zero-field splitting, D is often comparable in energy to typical superexchange interactions, J. In this case only the oxalate bridges provide a significant exchange interaction, and so we expect the compound to behave as a 1-D chain of interacting spins, as described by the Hamiltonian, eq .  1   H = - J   ∑   i      S   i   ⋅   S   i + 1

elements.content: However, realistic models are not available for such a system. In general, it is very rare to find exact theoretical results for infinitely extended interacting systems. Fisher has derived a model for χ(T) based upon a classical chain of isotropic (Heisenberg, D = 0) spins in the limit of S = ∞, which may be scaled to finite values of S. Hatfield has developed a numerical approach based upon an isotropic (D = 0) quantum approach. Similarly, there are models for perfect Ising systems (D = −∞). In the present case, the data are initially fitted with a Heisenberg model for an S = 3/2 antiferromagnetic chain. Here, we have used exact numerical full-matrix diagonalization techniques to calculate the magnetic susceptibility for rings of 9 and 10 S = 3/2 centers (). By averaging the curves, we can obtain a susceptibility that is more reliable to lower values of k B T/|J|. The averaged curve is well described by the polynomial given in eq , between 0.5 < k B T/|J| < 5.0. χ = N g 2 μ B 2 4 k B T 5 + 2.59277 x + 4.00094 x 2 − 0.23392 x 3 1 + 3.03193 x + 5.58780 x 2 + 7.92507 x 3 where x = |J|/k B T. Fitting the susceptibility data for 1 above 60 K, we obtain g = 2.738(5) and J/k B = −16.9(1). We do not attempt to fit low temperature data as this is much more likely to be significantly perturbed by the effects of zero-field splitting.

elements.content: Trying to account for the anisotropic nature of the Co(II) ions is nontrivial. However, Rueff et al. have proposed a very successful phenomenological relationship. This relationship takes some account of the magnetic coupling in 1-D chains and also a reduction in χT due to the effects of spin−orbit coupling. The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was modeled using a slightly modified version of Rueff’s equation (eq ). χ = N g 2 μ B 2 3 k B T ( 3.75 − α ) exp ( − D / k B T ) + α exp ( J / k B T ) where D is the spin−orbit coupling parameter and J is the magnetic coupling constant.

elements.content: Fitting the data from 300 to 9 K gives g = 2.814(2), D/k B = 86.2(4) K and J/k B = −16.03(3) K and α = 1.621(4) (Figure ). Below 9 K, the model diverges from our data. Despite the phenomenological nature of this analysis, several studies suggest that it simultaneously provides reasonable values for the magnetic coupling and spin−orbit interaction. Since few of the known [Co(ox)]∞ chain compounds have been treated with this model, we have reanalyzed data available from the literature (Table ) to provide comparison with our results.

We find that the model provides an excellent fit to the data with only four parameters, and values for g, the spin−orbit interaction, and magnetic couplings are reasonable and in good agreement with comparable literature values. From Table , it can be seen that systems with infinite chains of [Co(ox)]∞ give magnetic couplings mostly within quite a narrow range of 16−21 K. Thus, if it is possible to engineer a system containing these chains, it is possible to predict the magnitude of the magnetic interaction.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 2 (Figure ) shows a broad maximum at 50 K with χ max = 9.91 × 10−3 cm3 mol−1 before decreasing. The inverse susceptibility plot shows linear behavior above about 170 K, and modeling the data with the Curie−Weiss equation gives C = 1.308(2) cm3 mol−1 K and θ = −83.9(5) K. A plot of χT(T) shows a decreasing product on cooling with a value at 290 K of 1.016 cm3 mol−1 K. From the Curie constant and χT (290 K), we can derive g-values of 2.29 and 2.01, respectively. As χT has not reached its asymptotic value at 290 K, the g-value derived from χT (290 K) is likely to be low.

elements.content: Given the large separation of the [Ni(ox)]∞ chains by the ethylenediamine molecules and the insignificant superexchange coupling that ethylenediamine would provide, it is likely that we are seeing a good example of a 1-D, S = 1 antiferromagnet. Such systems are of great current interest as at low temperatures we may expect to see a rare quantum state known as the Haldane phase, which shows unconventional magnetic ordering. This Haldane state is easily destroyed by interchain couplings and significant single-ion anisotropy. The susceptibility and χT(T) data for 2 were modeled using the equation of Souletie et al. (eq ), which accounts for the presence of a “Haldane gap” between the ground and excited spin states of such an antiferromagnetically coupled S = 1 chain. χ = N g 2 μ B 2 k B T 0.125 exp ( − 0.451 J / k B T ) + 0.564 exp ( − 1.793 J / k B T ) We obtain g = 2.194(2) and J/k B = −39.3(1) K. The value of the Haldane gap can be calculated as 0.421 × J/k B = 16.5 K.

elements.content: Castillo et al. report an effect of the geometry of the coordination sphere around the Ni(II) ion on the magnetic properties in oxalate-bridged Ni(II) systems indicating that in systems where the chain is planar with respect to Ni(II) and oxalate, the coupling is slightly lower than in cases where the chain shows a zigzag conformation. Comparison of the coupling value in 2 with other linear [Ni(ox)]∞ systems shows that they are toward the top of the expected range.

elements.content: The simple structure of M(ox)(en) (1 and 2) that we report has both an aesthetically pleasing quality and a clear and direct relevance to the study of model magnetic systems. It is essentially the structure that we had planned to obtain. Since similar 2-D nets are known, albeit with rigid amines, we set out to form the present structures by carefully controlling the M/ox/en stoichiometry to ensure that enough metal coordination sites were available for the oxalate to bridge. The hydrothermal synthetic approach allowed us both to form crystals of an otherwise very low solubility product and to control redox processes in the solution. In general, superheated aqueous oxalate solutions are mildly reducing, and thus prevent the oxidation of the metals (particularly the facile Co(II) to Co(III) process).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The simple structure of M(ox)(en) (1 and 2) that we report has both an aesthetically pleasing quality and a clear and direct relevance to the study of model magnetic systems. It is essentially the structure that we had planned to obtain. Since similar 2-D nets are known, albeit with rigid amines, we set out to form the present structures by carefully controlling the M/ox/en stoichiometry to ensure that enough metal coordination sites were available for the oxalate to bridge. The hydrothermal synthetic approach allowed us both to form crystals of an otherwise very low solubility product and to control redox processes in the solution. In general, superheated aqueous oxalate solutions are mildly reducing, and thus prevent the oxidation of the metals (particularly the facile Co(II) to Co(III) process).

elements.content: In these two isostructural compounds, the physical differences are essentially due to the addition of a single electron in going from a Co(II) d 7 system to a Ni(II) d 8 analogue. While the difference this electron makes upon the structure is quite inconsequential, the effect on the electronic and magnetic properties is very significant, with not only large differences in magnetic coupling interactions, but also the fundamental difference in the theoretical magnetic ground states. The high local symmetries make 2 particularly appealing for further magnetic studies.

cln_elements.content:
CoSO4·7H2O (281 mg, 1.00 mmol), ethylenediamine (0.2 mL, 3.0 mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (127 mg, 1.00 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) were heated in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr) to 150 °C under autogenious pressure for 72 h. Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a brown microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 38 mg (18%).

Synthesis of Ni(en)(ox) (<bold>2</bold>)

Ni(OH)2 (100 mg, 1.07 mmol), ethylenediammonium bis(hydrogen oxalate) monohydrate (900 mg, 3.49 mmol), and distilled water (8 mL) were heated in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr) to 180 °C under autogenous pressure for 28 h. Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a blue microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 60 mg (27%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Co(en)(ox) (1)

CoSO4⋅7H2O (281 mg, 1.00 mmol), ethylenediamine (0.2 mL, 3.0 mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (127 mg, 1.00 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) were heated in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr) to 150 °C under autogenious pressure for 72 h. Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a brown microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 38 mg (18%).

Synthesis of Ni(en)(ox) (2)

Ni(OH)2 (100 mg, 1.07 mmol), ethylenediammonium bis(hydrogen oxalate) monohydrate (900 mg, 3.49 mmol), and distilled water (8 mL) were heated in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr) to 180 °C under autogenous pressure for 28 h. Upon cooling, the product was obtained as a blue microcrystalline product, which was washed with water and acetone and allowed to dry. Yield 60 mg (27%).

cln_elements.content:
We present two 2-D network compounds built from [M(II)(oxalate)]∞ chains (M = Co, 1; Ni, 2) bridged into 2-D networks by ethylenediamine. Both show antiferromagnetic interactions (1: J/k B = −16.03(3) K; 2: J/k B = −39.3(1) K), and 2 is a candidate Haldane antiferromagnet.

Found C: 23.06, H: 4.05, N: 13.26. NiC4H8N2O4 requires C: 23.23, H: 3.90, N: 13.54. IR (KBr, cm−1) 3450 (w), 3314 (s), 3266 (m), 3156 (w), 2981 (m), 2915 (w), 1631 (s), 1479 (m), 1361 (m), 1318 (s), 1105 (s), 1020 (s), 802 (s), 626 (m), 488 (s), 455 (m). UV (BaSO4 matrix, diffuse reflectance, cm−1) 9700 3A2 g → 3T2 g; 14400 → 1Eg; 16700 → 3T1 g(F); 24200 → 3T1 g(P); 35300 (oxalate).

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibility of 1 (Figure ) shows a broad maximum at 18 K with χ max = 37.56 × 10−3 cm3 mol−1 before decreasing. The inverse susceptibility plot shows linear behavior above ∼160 K, and modeling the data with the Curie−Weiss equation gives a Curie constant, C = 3.72(1) cm3 mol−1 K and a Weiss constant, θ = −61.4(9) K. On cooling, the χT(T) plot decreases from a value of 3.07 cm3 mol−1 K at 290 K. From C and χT (290 K), we can obtain g-values of 2.82 and 2.56, respectively. The lower estimate of the g-value from χT (290 K) is due to not having reached the asymptotic limit at this temperature. Our expectation in this system is fairly straightforward. The octahedrally coordinated Co(II) ion has an orbitally degenerate ground state and generally shows a significantly anisotropic spin moment. In particular, the zero-field splitting, D is often comparable in energy to typical superexchange interactions, J. In this case only the oxalate bridges provide a significant exchange interaction, and so we expect the compound to behave as a 1-D chain of interacting spins, as described by the Hamiltonian, eq . H = − J ∑ i S i · S i + 1
